meaning_mnemonic:
This is an abbreviation of 総理大臣 (prime minister), so this means <vocabulary>prime minister</vocabulary>.

As you learned with 総理大臣, this word is used only for the <vocabulary>Japanese prime minister</vocabulary>.

You know 構える, which can mean to assume a stance? This is the noun version, making it <vocabulary>stance</vocabulary>.

構え is often used to describe specific stances or <vocabulary>posture</vocabulary>s, both in a literal and figurative sense. In this vein, it can also convey the notion of being mentally and physically prepared for action. Additionally, 構え is also used to refer to the <vocabulary>structure</vocabulary> of something, often focusing on visual appearance.

We're going to <kanji>deal with</kanji> it by <kanji>put</kanji>ting this up your butt and giving you the <vocabulary>treatment</vocabulary> you need. Kancho!

処置 is commonly used when treating injuries or illnesses. It can also refer to deciding how to handle a situation or the act of handling it, but in these cases, people usually use 処理 instead.

An <kanji>exhibition</kanji> that you <kanji>look at</kanji> and all the people come <kanji>meet</kanji> together. Well, that just sounds like the description of an <vocabulary>exposition</vocabulary>.

The kanji means <kanji>delicate</kanji>, and so does this word. Something that's <vocabulary>delicate</vocabulary> is probably also <vocabulary>faint</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>indistinct</vocabulary>. So use 微か to describe things like faint sounds, delicate breezes, and indistinct memories.

If you <kanji>shift</kanji> the place you <kanji>dwell</kanji>, you’re <kanji>someone</kanji> that we call an <vocabulary>emigrant</vocabulary>, an <vocabulary>immigrant</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>migrant</vocabulary>. Welcome, friend!

You can use this word both for people who migrate between countries and those who migrate within the same country.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stuffed</kanji>. The vocab word is <vocabulary>to be stuffed</vocabulary>, as in something is stuffed and you're not doing the stuffing. You know this because when it comes to まる the cat, he stuffs himself into boxes on his own, so you don't have to stuff him into boxes for him. It just happens, and you can watch and be entertained (obviously you need to go watch some Maru videos if you haven't on YouTube, just saying).
The <kanji>alluring</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is the power of <vocabulary>allure</vocabulary>.

並ぶ is when something is lining up. 並べる is when you're lining something up. In other words, 並べる is transitive. It means <vocabulary>to line something up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put something in order</vocabulary>. You know this because when it comes to <reading>bear</reading>s (べる), you have to line them up yourself, because they won't be doing it for you, that's for sure.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>scarce</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>scarce</vocabulary>.
We are <kanji>lack</kanji>ing and things are <kanji>scarce</kanji>. We have a <vocabulary>lack</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>scarcity</vocabulary> of resources.
冷たい is "cold." This is the verb version, so you're making something cold. This word is <vocabulary>to chill something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cool something</vocabulary>.
Let's <kanji>bind</kanji> this <kanji>marriage</kanji> up with a <vocabulary>marriage</vocabulary>. No better way to make a marriage happen than a marriage, right?
When you <kanji>request</kanji> <kanji>marriage</kanji> with someone else, you are doing a <vocabulary>marriage proposal</vocabulary>. Will you marry me, Brad Pitt?
You know that 旅行 is a <kanji>trip</kanji>. The other part is <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>marriage</kanji>. What's the trip you go on after a new marriage? The <vocabulary>honeymoon</vocabulary>!
<kanji>Not yet</kanji> <kanji>marriage</kanji>? You haven't been married. You're <vocabulary>unmarried</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>prolong</kanji> and this verb means <vocabulary>to prolong something</vocabulary>.

延ばす conveys the idea of expanding upon something that already exists to make it longer, often in terms of time or physical distance. For example, it can refer to delaying a schedule or extending a railway.
<kanji>Prolong</kanji> it for a <kanji>long</kanji> while. We need more time. We need a <vocabulary>prolonging</vocabulary> or <vocabulary> extension</vocabulary> of some kind.
Can we <kanji>prolong</kanji> this <kanji>period of time</kanji> to a later date? I want <vocabulary>to postpone</vocabulary>, if possible.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>pleasant</kanji>? It is also <vocabulary>pleasant</vocabulary>.

When you have the <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>pleasant</kanji>ness, you are experiencing <vocabulary>pleasure</vocabulary>.

While 快感 can describe the thrill of achieving something satisfying, it's often associated with <vocabulary>pleasurable feeling</vocabulary>s from taboo or unusual experiences. For example, it might refer to the pleasure of teasing someone, indulging in a bad habit like picking earwax, or feeling sensual delight.

It's <kanji>pleasant</kanji> but also <kanji>fast</kanji>. When getting on a train, it's nice to find a train that's both of these things. What makes it pleasant? That would be the <vocabulary>high speed</vocabulary>. What makes it fast? Also the <vocabulary>high speed</vocabulary>. Really, if you're on a train you'd rather get to your destination sooner than later, so a high speed 快速 train is the way to go.
Things that are <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>pleasant</kanji> are <vocabulary>unpleasant</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>uncomfortable</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>nostalgia</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>nostalgic</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>push</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to push</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>photograph</kanji>. When you make that into a verb, it becomes <vocabulary>to take a picture</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to take a video</vocabulary>. Basically, it's for any form of shooting you do with a camera!

If you <kanji>photograph</kanji> a <kanji>shadow</kanji>, you're obviously doing some kind of <vocabulary>photography</vocabulary>. (In the old days photography meant using light to burn shadows onto special paper, but now it's all fancy and digital.) This isn't just still photography though; it also means <vocabulary>filming</vocabulary> (as in a video or movie). Basically, if it has to do with taking photos or video, 撮影 is your dude.

<kanji>Steal</kanji>ing <kanji>photograph</kanji>s of you. Wait, you didn't know you were being photographed or filmed? That's <vocabulary>secret photography</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>secret filming</vocabulary>. Creeeeeepy.
診断 is a <kanji>diagnosis</kanji>. Make this into a verb, and you have <vocabulary>to diagnose</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>country</kanji>'s <kanji>flag</kanji> is the flag they use for their nation. It's the <vocabulary>national flag</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>back</kanji> <kanji>scene</kanji> is the scene going on in the back. You don't really notice it, because it's the <vocabulary>background</vocabulary>.

Experiencing a <kanji>renew</kanji>al of <kanji>life</kanji> means going through a process of <vocabulary>rehabilitation</vocabulary>.

 更生 generally refers to rehabilitation from various issues such as addiction, crime,  delinquency, or personal struggles. Ideally, this leads to <vocabulary>reforming oneself</vocabulary> and reintegrating into society.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>float</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to float</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>float</kanji>ing <kanji>world</kanji> <kanji>painting</kanji> is what you call an <vocabulary>ukiyo-e woodblock print</vocabulary> in Japan. The "floating world" refers to an evanescent world that is impermanent (floating), just as beauty and entertainment are. Back in the day, this type of art was made into woodblock prints and paintings. Unfortunately, we don't have a name for these in English because they're so unique and special, but they come up more than you'd think, so get used to ukiyo-e!

A <kanji>float</kanji>ing <kanji>spirit</kanji>? If your spirit is floating around (in matters of love), then you might be likely to <vocabulary>cheat</vocabulary> on your partner. Careful — once it starts, your <vocabulary>cheating</vocabulary> could turn into a full-blown <vocabulary>affair</vocabulary>.

浮気 means cheating in a relationship, whether you're dating or married. But even harmless flirting can sometimes count as 浮気, since it indicates your spirit is "floating" and not as securely tied to your partner as they'd like…

When you have a <kanji>thirst</kanji>, you tend <vocabulary>to become thirsty</vocabulary>.

Note that this does not mean “to be thirsty” by itself, but only in combination with 喉, as in 喉が渇く.
A <kanji>leak</kanji> of <kanji>water</kanji> is a <vocabulary>water leakage</vocabulary>.

Something is <kanji>leak</kanji>ing and whatever is leaking is <kanji>exit</kanji>ing what it was in before. This is when a <vocabulary>leak</vocabulary> occurs.

漏出 is a formal word that means <vocabulary>leakage</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>spillage</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>seepage</vocabulary>. It's often used for physical leaks of substances like liquids, gases, or other materials.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>leak</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to leak</vocabulary>.

漏れる can be used for both physical and abstract leakage, like water or gas leaking, sound or light seeping out, or information or emotions being revealed unintentionally.

Your feel as if your cheeks are <kanji>illuminate</kanji>d when you start <vocabulary>to feel shy</vocabulary>. Probably illuminated in red, which is why this also means <vocabulary>to blush</vocabulary>. 

照れる means <vocabulary>to be bashful</vocabulary>, often in situations where the embarrassment stems from modesty rather than serious discomfort. It's used to describe feeling self-conscious in an endearing way, such as blushing due to praise, attention, or being teased in a lighthearted manner.
<kanji>Illuminate</kanji> and make things <kanji>bright</kanji>, my <vocabulary>illumination</vocabulary>!
If you <kanji>exit</kanji> that <kanji>edition</kanji> out of your hands and into the world, you've gotten something published! That is <vocabulary>publishing</vocabulary>.
You have <kanji>edition</kanji> <kanji>rights</kanji> over this. This edition is yours, and if anyone copies this edition, they get in trouble. You have <vocabulary>copyright</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>first</kanji> <kanji>edition</kanji> is the <vocabulary>first edition</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>steal</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to steal</vocabulary>.

You are <kanji>strong</kanji> so you break into someone's home, hold them up, then <kanji>steal</kanji> from them. Ha ha! Take that, next door neighbor! This is a <vocabulary>burglary</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>robbery</vocabulary>, depending on how crazy you get after you use that strength to break down that door.
<kanji>Steal</kanji> what other people <kanji>make</kanji>? Wow. Way to go. That is <vocabulary>plagiarism</vocabulary>.
These are <kanji>stolen</kanji> (steal) <kanji>goods</kanji>. So, I'll give you a deal, because, you know, they're <vocabulary>stolen goods</vocabulary>.

If 幼稚 is <kanji>childish</kanji>, then a <kanji>garden</kanji> for childish people would be a place full of lots of children, probably growing in some way. When you're growing little children in a garden, you're putting them into some kind of school. In this case, it's a <vocabulary>kindergarten</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>cut</kanji> <kanji>token</kanji> is a token you cut out from a sheet of paper into smaller sheets, and each of these pieces is a <vocabulary>ticket</vocabulary>.

You put <kanji>one cup of liquid</kanji>... no, one full cup of liquid <kanji>spirit</kanji> into what you're doing. None of this half-cup garbage. A full one. That means you're going at it <vocabulary>with all one's might</vocabulary>.

Your 精神 is your spirit or your mind. If you add 的 to it, you get <vocabulary>mental</vocabulary>. It can mean <vocabulary>spiritual</vocabulary> too, but it more often shows up in reference to a person's mental or <vocabulary>emotional</vocabulary> state.

精神 is your spirit or mind, the non-physical part of you. When it's <kanji>sick</kanji>, it's a <vocabulary>mental illness</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mental disorder</vocabulary>.

Note that the term 精神病, when used on its own, carries a stigma and is considered a bit disrespectful and outdated.

Trace something back through its <kanji>lineage</kanji> to determine what <vocabulary>type</vocabulary> of thing it is. 

〜系 is a suffix you can attach casually to a word to classify it as a <vocabulary>genre</vocabulary> or group, like 理系 (science-oriented fields), おしゃれ系 (trendy or stylish people), or 日系 (Japanese descendants).

The 日 stands for 日本 here, making it mean "Japanese." So what's a more common way of saying Japanese <kanji>lineage</kanji>? That would be <vocabulary>Japanese descent</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Japanese origin</vocabulary>.

日系 can be used for both people and entities, such as 日系アメリカ人 (Japanese-American) or 日系企業 (Japanese-operated company).
You know 太陽 means "sun," so hopefully you can guess what a sun <kanji>system</kanji> is. That's right — it's the <vocabulary>solar system</vocabulary>!

Give a <kanji>body</kanji> to a <kanji>system</kanji> to make it a real, structured system, you know? Then add 的 to it to make it <vocabulary>systematic</vocabulary>.

体系的 is a formal word for something that follows a clear structure or framework, often used in academic contexts. For example, you might hear it when discussing a systematic approach to solving a problem or organizing information systematically.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>die out</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to die out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to come to an end</vocabulary>.

絶える is mostly used for when something that was ongoing comes to an end, like breath stopping, laughter fading away, a supply being cut off, or foot traffic dying down. You know this because when something dies out, nothing is left but thin air (える).
<kanji>The next</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is just that, <vocabulary>the next day</vocabulary>.
<kanji>The next</kanji> <kanji>month</kanji> is <vocabulary>the next month</vocabulary>.
<kanji>The next</kanji> <kanji>morning</kanji> is <vocabulary>the next morning</vocabulary>.
<kanji>The next</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> is <vocabulary>the next year</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

With just <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>look at</kanji> something you're able to take in all the info you need, because that something is <vocabulary>a list</vocabulary>. A nice list that gives you <vocabulary>an overview</vocabulary> at a glance. Perfect for all that <vocabulary>looking over</vocabulary> you have to do. You busy consumer of information, you.

一覧 usually refers to a neat list you can skim over easily to get the info you need, like a guest list or a data table. With する, it becomes a pretty formal verb for looking over something in a quick way, like skimming through a report or casually checking out a place.

ご覧 is the polite noun form of 見る and means <vocabulary>looking at</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>seeing</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>watching</vocabulary>. It's often paired with 〜になる, as in ご覧になる, which is a respectful way to describe someone else's 見る action.

Some other common phrases you might hear are ご覧ください (please take a look) or ご覧のとおり (as you can see). They're formal but common in polite speech, such as in customer service or business presentations. ご覧 can even be used on its own as a gentle command, like ほら、そこをご覧 ("Hey, look over there").
If you <kanji>view</kanji> and <kanji>look at</kanji> something, you are <vocabulary>viewing</vocabulary> that thing, or <vocabulary>watching</vocabulary> it.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>poor</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>poor</vocabulary>.
You are <kanji>poor</kanji> and money / food is very <kanji>scarce</kanji> for you, making you <vocabulary>poor</vocabulary>.

When your <kanji>purchase</kanji> <kanji>enter</kanji>s into effect, you have made your <vocabulary>purchase</vocabulary>.

購入 is a relatively formal word for the act of purchasing something.

You purchase and buy something? That's some serious purchasing. 購買 is a formal term for the act of purchasing goods or services, mostly in business or economic contexts. It's often combined with another word, like in 購買意欲 (consumer appetite) or 購買力 (purchasing power). In some contexts, 購買 can also refer to a school shop or campus store, especially in high schools or universities.

This is a <kanji>purchase</kanji>d <kanji>read</kanji> — especially one that comes regularly. In other words, a <vocabulary>subscription</vocabulary>.

購読 specifically refers to paying for a subscription to some kind of reading material, like a newspaper or magazine, so be sure not to use it for free subscriptions!
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>go beyond</kanji>, the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to go beyond</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>go beyond</kanji> your <kanji>rights</kanji>, you are going too far. You're doing what you're not supposed to do, and you're overstepping your authority.

Something is <kanji>reverse</kanji>, that much you know. The さま comes from 様, which could mean <kanji>manner</kanji>. So, something that is in a "reverse manner," is something that is <vocabulary>upside down</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>play</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to play</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>play</kanji> <kanji>park</kanji> <kanji>ground</kanji> is where you go play. It's fun. It's an <vocabulary>amusement park</vocabulary>!

Everything is <kanji>suitable</kanji> and <kanji>right</kanji>. Therefore it is <vocabulary>appropriate</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>proper</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>suitable</vocabulary>. Strangely enough, this also means <vocabulary>irresponsible</vocabulary>. Maybe it's because when everything is suitable and right for you, you're taking too much and not leaving enough for everyone else, making you irresponsible?
Something that is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>suitable</kanji> is <vocabulary>unsuitable</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>inappropriate</vocabulary>.
登録 is <kanji>registration</kanji>. Make that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to register</vocabulary>.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Leave Someone With Someone Else

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>deposit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to deposit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to entrust</vocabulary>. 

You use 預ける when you leave something in someone else's care for a while, expecting to get it back. For example, you can use 預ける when you deposit money in a bank, leave your coat in a cloakroom, or even when you park your bicycle in a parking area. You can also use it when you leave your child with grandparents or leave your dog at a pet hotel.
<kanji>Deposit</kanji> your <kanji>gold</kanji> here in the bank. When you do that, it is a <vocabulary>bank deposit</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>decorate</kanji>. The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to decorate</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>clothes</kanji> with which I <kanji>decorate</kanji> myself with is my <vocabulary>attire</vocabulary> or my <vocabulary>fashion</vocabulary>.

The 電 is what powers electric things. Many times, these electric things light up (especially back in the day, when electricity did this a lot more than other things). So, you have "lighting." Then, you have <kanji>decorate</kanji>. So, if you decorate with lighting, you have <vocabulary>decorative lighting</vocabulary>.

This is quite a specific word that is generally used as a product category for decorative lighting. It’s a less common word than other expressions, such as デコレーションライト or イルミネーションライト.

The kanji is <kanji>boisterous</kanji>. The verb version is <vocabulary>to make noise</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be boisterous</vocabulary>. Basically, you're being boisterous when you make a lot of noise, so that's where it comes from.
<kanji>Boisterous</kanji> <kanji>sound</kanji> is when there's a lot of <vocabulary>noise</vocabulary> around you. It's the <vocabulary>din</vocabulary> of the crowd or environment.
攻撃 is an <kanji>attack</kanji>. Make that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>previous</kanji> <kanji>extent</kanji> of time was <vocabulary>a little while ago</vocabulary>. Just think to a previous extent of time that was indeed a little while ago. Now, associate!

先程 is limited to a relatively brief time frame within the same day. So it can be used for something mentioned earlier in a speech or at an event from <vocabulary>earlier in the day</vocabulary>, but not for something from a few days ago. 先程 is also polite and formal, so it's generally used in professional or respectful settings.
If 官僚 is "bureaucracy," then adding a 的 to it would make it <vocabulary>bureaucratic</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>whole</kanji> <kanji>reason</kanji> our country is still running is because of our "minister" (大臣). Which minister? The <vocabulary>prime minister</vocabulary>, of course. Without our prime minister, we'd all be doomed I say. DOOMED!

Unlike 首相, which can be used for any prime minister, this word is used only for the <vocabulary>Japanese prime minister</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shift</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be shifted</vocabulary>. You know that this is the one where something is shifted (and you're not doing the shifting), because it's really <reading>ru</reading>de (る) to be shifted, and you don't like it when people do it to you (because it happens quite a lot, strangely).
怖い is "scary." This is a verb version, making it <vocabulary>to be scared</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be afraid of</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>master</kanji> is the <vocabulary>owner</vocabulary> who has dominance or control over something.

主 is usually used with other words to indicate a person who owns something or who is principally involved in an action. That might sound a little vague, so check out the collocations and context sentences to get a better grasp of this word!

You know that 埋まる is "to be buried." This verb is also <vocabulary>to be buried</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get buried</vocabulary>. 

However, there's a slight difference between them. 埋まる focuses on the subject itself getting buried or filled, while 埋もれる highlights the sense of something being hidden or obscured by being covered. So you could use it to describe a yard covered in snow or your talent being overshadowed in a competitive environment. 

You can remember this nuance because it's <reading>more rare</reading> (もれる) to see something completely buried and covered up.

Something that's <kanji>behind</kanji> your <kanji>back</kanji> is in the <vocabulary>background</vocabulary>. It's also probably plotting against you, <vocabulary>behind the scenes</vocabulary>. Sneaky, sneaky.

<kanji>Pleasant</kanji> <kanji>comfort</kanji> brings you a lot of <vocabulary>pleasure</vocabulary>.

快楽 is more commonly used in writing and often describes pleasure with a sense of indulgence, especially physical or sensory pleasure.
Something that is both <kanji>pleasant</kanji> and <kanji>suitable</kanji> is still really <vocabulary>pleasant</vocabulary>.

If you <kanji>become</kanji> aware of something to an <kanji>extent</kanji> you'll end up saying <vocabulary>I see</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>that makes sense</vocabulary>! But you won't see if you didn't become aware enough. So it's that extent of understanding you're trying to reach before you can chime in with an "Ahh, <vocabulary>indeed</vocabulary>."

成程 is a common expression used to acknowledge understanding or express agreement with something that's just been explained to you. It can be used in both formal and informal conversations. Just keep in mind this word is usually written in kana!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
If the <kanji>extent</kanji> you go to do something is properly (よく) done, then you did it <vocabulary>properly</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>well</vocabulary>!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>smell</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to smell</vocabulary>.

Although 匂う is technically a neutral term, it often means <vocabulary>to smell bad</vocabulary>. To emphasize the stinkiness, you can also use the kanji 臭 instead of 匂.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wet</kanji> or <kanji>damp</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to wet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to dampen</vocabulary> something.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. The kanji itself means <kanji>draw near</kanji>, and the verb version is about making or letting something draw near to something else. That's why it means <vocabulary>to move something close to</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to pull something over</vocabulary>, and also <vocabulary>to contribute something</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>retreat</kanji>, and this verb version is when you make something retreat. In other words, it means <vocabulary>to repel something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to dismiss something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to reject something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You repel something, like bad luck. You reject something, like a proposal.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>pain</kanji>, and this verb is transitive, so it means to inflict pain. In other words, it's <vocabulary>to injure something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hurt someone</vocabulary>.

This verb focuses on the pain involved in an injury, so it can only be used for things that feel pain, like people and body parts.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Isn't that fencetastic?
Ready for this one? An <kanji>iron</kanji> <kanji>fence </kanji> is an <vocabulary>iron fence</vocabulary>. Don't you love it when it's straightforward?
If you combine 電気 (electricity) with 柵 (<kanji>fence</kanji>) you have an <vocabulary>electric fence</vocabulary>. Shocking, I know.

Here we have <kanji>I</kanji> followed by the particle が, giving us a somewhat old-fashioned and stylized way of say <vocabulary>our</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>one's own</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>my</vocabulary>.

One explanation for this is that in ancient Japanese, が was used as a possessive particle, much like の is in modern Japanese.

The kanji means <kanji>push</kanji>, and this verb means things like <vocabulary>to hold something down</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to grasp something</vocabulary>. This verb is pretty versatile, and you can use it if you're holding down a piece of paper, holding a cloth to a wound, or grasping a concept.

Pig bone ramen is tonkotsu ramen or, very logically indeed, pork bone ramen. 豚骨ラーメン is a type of Japanese ramen made with a rich, creamy broth from 豚骨 (pork bones). The bones are simmered for hours to extract the flavors, resulting in a flavorful and hearty soup. It's so delicious, you'll be back for more. Bone appetit!

Your <kanji>joint</kanji> <kanji>joint</kanji>s are your <vocabulary>various joints</vocabulary>, or even <vocabulary>every joint</vocabulary> in your body, or a specific body part. When we're not talking about the joints in your body, this means something like <vocabulary>various parts</vocabulary>, referring to various parts of a whole.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Make A Complete Collection Of

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember 揃う, "to be complete"? This is the transitive version of that, and it means things like <vocabulary>to arrange something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to gather something</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to align something</vocabulary>.

This one is a little tricky to understand and translate well. At its core, this verb describes the act of arranging all of the necessary things for something. But it can also describe aligning certain things in a uniform, matching manner. If this still isn't clear, have a careful look at our context sentences and collocations!

Well, you've got <kanji>iron</kanji> and you've got a <kanji>board</kanji>. You'd probably just call it an <vocabulary>iron plate</vocabulary>, though. But this often isn't just any iron plate. If you could guess from the reading, it's often used in cooking as an <vocabulary>iron griddle</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>teppan grill</vocabulary>. Ever heard of Teppanyaki?

Figuratively, it means a <vocabulary>sure thing</vocabulary> or a practically guaranteed success. For example, you can use 鉄板 for a racehorse almost certain to win, or a joke that consistently gets big laughs.
This is just the kanji <kanji>niece</kanji> as a vocab, so this also means <vocabulary>niece</vocabulary>!
